title: 17-year-old boy drowns, father injured, in rough surf at Hampton Beach in N.H.
description: The boy's father, who tried to save his son, was in stable condition at Exeter Hospital Sunday night, New Hampshire State Police said.
content:
The boy was not identified as he is a juvenile. His father was in stable condition at Exeter Hospital, New Hampshire State Police said in a statement Sunday night.

A 17-year-old boy presumably drowned off Hampton Beach in New Hampshire Sunday night, and his father nearly went under trying to save him, authorities said.

The boy was pronounced dead at the hospital.

Authorities warned of dangerous conditions at coastal beaches over the weekend due to high surf generated by Hurricane Erin.

A State Police marine patrol unit responded to the report of a possible drowning at the beach at 6:46 p.m. on Sunday, the statement said.

The boy’s father went into the water to try and rescue him but also became distressed, State Police said. Lifeguards were not on patrol at the time but were called to the beach and quickly responded, according to the statement.

The lifeguards were able to get to the boy and his father and bring them to shore, State Police said. They provided medical aid to the boy once on shore.

No further information was released late Sunday night.

Late summer has been a treacherous time at Hampton Beach. Authorities last week said lifeguards had performed 144 water rescues in a single week, the Globe reported.

Adam Sennott can be reached at adam.sennott@globe.com.
summary: A 17-year-old boy reportedly drowned off Hampton Beach in New Hampshire, while his father nearly drowned in the rough surf. The boy was not identified as he is a juvenile and his father is in a stable condition at Exeter Hospital. The incident occurred at 6:46 p.m. on Sunday. Lifeguards were called to the beach and quickly brought the boy to shore, and he was pronounced dead at the hospital.
shortSummary: A 17-year-old boy drowned at Hampton Beach, New Hampshire, while his father was injured in the water, prompting a safety alert from authorities.

scraped_sources.text:
It was a busy week for the Hampton Hasselhoffs.
Lifeguards at Hampton Beach in New Hampshire last week rescued more than 140 people who were caught in rip currents, including 51 rescues on Aug. 12 alone, officials said.
“All patrons were rescued safely without [any] further medical attention needed,” State Beach Patrol Chief Patrick Murphy said by email.
Lifeguards performed 144 rescues last week from rip currents, and 20 more people were rescued over the weekend, though not all from rip currents, he said.
“With Hurricane Erin coming up the coast, the NH State Beach Patrol-Ocean Lifeguards are encouraging all beachgoers to always swim near a lifeguard,” Murphy wrote.
Hampton Beach has lifeguard coverage from 9 a.m. to 5:30 p.m., he said.
Last year, 66 people died in rip currents along US shores, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. A rip current is a powerful, narrow channel of water flowing away from the beach and often extending through the breaker zone where waves form.
People caught in a rip current should not try to fight it but go out with the current, then swim parallel to the shoreline before turning back toward the shore.

Erin is on track to pass hundreds of miles from the East Coast, but the Category 4 storm will still produce some rough surf and dangerous rip currents along New England’s coastline, starting Tuesday.
Erin continues to churn in the Atlantic, packing winds of 140 miles per hour and is expected to begin turning north over the next several days and parallel the East Coast. The high surf and rip currents are forecast to ramp up Thursday and Friday as the storm passes the Northeast, the Globe’s weather team reported Monday.

argos_summary: A 17‑year‑old boy drowned off Hampton Beach, New Hampshire, and his father nearly drowned while attempting a rescue. Lifeguards, who were not on patrol at the time, quickly responded and brought both the boy and his father to shore, providing medical aid to the boy before he was pronounced dead at the hospital. Authorities warned of dangerous surf conditions caused by Hurricane Erin, which has increased rip currents along the coast. In the week prior, lifeguards performed 144 rescues from rip currents, underscoring the heightened risk for beachgoers.
